awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Testing Individualized Cognitive Training Interventions Based on a Multifaceted Theory of Working Memory
awd_abstract_narration:
Working memory is the ability to actively maintain, manipulate, and retrieve relevant information during everyday tasks. An individual's working memory functioning is strongly and positively related to important outcomes such as intelligence, reading comprehension, mathematic proficiency, and resistance to distraction. An important question is what specific cognitive processes can explain why working memory is so critical for these diverse aspects of behavior. A related question is whether increasing a person's working memory functioning via computerized memory exercises will lead to improvements not just in working memory but also in related outcomes, such as intelligence and reading comprehension. This research project will provide the foundation for new theoretical perspectives about working memory that have the potential to drastically alter the future of cognitive training research and commercialization. The information gained via this project comes at a critical juncture, as the public, K-12, and medical use of computerized cognitive training is increasing, along with recent estimates of billions of US dollars spent on such computerized training. The investigators will provide workshops and lectures to students, faculty, community members, and K-12 teachers and administrators, both in-person and via Internet-based materials. In addition, the project will provide a variety of hands-on research opportunities for graduate, undergraduate, and high school students.

The project will investigate a novel approach to cognitive training, by first identifying specific working memory strengths and weaknesses in a large sample of young adults, and then developing specific cognitive training exercises that target an individual's working memory functioning. This approach differs from the typical one-size-fits-all method of cognitive training that does not consider the individual's particular cognitive profile. Before and after training, participants will complete various cognitive tests designed to assess whether the training leads to very specific improvements (i.e., outcomes similar to the training program) or broader improvements (i.e., intelligence, reading comprehension). The design of the project will provide the strongest and clearest evidence yet about the potential utility of working memory training to produce meaningful changes in working memory, intelligence, and reading comprehension.

por.por_cntn:
This research addressed fundamental questions about why individuals vary in cognitive abilities important for higher-order cognition, and what an intervention that is structured to address specific cognitive deficits can do in terms of leading to improvements in important real-world skills. By combining both differential and experimental approaches, this project was truly unique in understanding individual differences in working-memory capacity and evaluating working-memory training and transfer. The collaborative nature of this proposal was particularly well-suited for the objectives of this project. This research team worked collaboratively to carry out all phases of this project and worked together to collect a large amount of data from college students at  Purdue University, Arizona State University, and the University of Oregon.  Based on the data that we collected we published multiple scientific papers on cognitive assesment, cognitive training, and individual differences methodology.  Research papers are still emerging from this project which was significantly delayed by COVID-19. In sum, this research project provided the foundation for new theoretical perspectives about working-memory capacity that have the potential to drastically alter the future of working-memory training research and commercialization.

This proposal addressed a significant need to identify and evaluate working-memory training as a means to improve cognition, and disseminated knowledge about working-memory training to students, educators, and the broader community. This proposal involved numerous activities that increased this project’s benefit to society, with two main focuses: (1) a detailed plan to disseminate working-memory training information to students, faculty, community members, and K-12 teachers and administrators; and (2) provided a variety of research opportunities for individuals with otherwise limited access (underrepresented groups, students at less-research intensive colleges and universities, and local high school students). The research team publicized the research via courses and talks in psychology and other related fields, along with community lectures and discussions as part of various speaker series. The team worked to provide a variety of options for students to participate in the proposed research, including continuing the PI’s involvement in the Summer Research Opportunity Program, whose goal is to encourage undergraduate students from social and economic backgrounds that are underrepresented in academia to pursue research and enhance their preparation for graduate study. Overall, this project was expected to have a broad positive impact on numerous fields in and out of psychology, and provided valuable information to the growing number of community members that use commercialized working-memory training products. The results of this research program hope to be generalizable and influential well beyond the period of this grant.
